characters: I'D GLADLY STAKE MY ALL ON THIS PROJECT
I'D STAKE MY ALL ON THIS PROJECT
I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS PROJECT
ON MATT AND FELLOW CAST MEMBERS
MUSIC NOW EMPHASIZING THE TENSION OF THE PRE-SHOW ATMOSPH
VITAMIN B, VITAMIN A, OSCILLOCOCCINUM, PROZAC, CALCIUM, T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA briskly retreats as FORTY, HIGHLY CHARGED,  ATTRACTIVE, YOUNG PEOPLE march towards it. Each side of t frame is black as this troupe of young actors moves up th middle, everyone talking, grinning, squealing,... everyon having the "high" of their lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the troupe, with geometric precision, spills into a la room (containing a raised dance floor); the CAMERA begins move past dancing couples as a legend appears: 'This is 1975 and Matt Hobbs is singled out for the first time.' And now the CAMERA reveals MATT HOBBS. His open, friendly American face slips between some of the many cracks in hi profession. The face at 26, and forever more, not arresti enough for a leading man; not quirky enough for a "charac Matt must briefly walk on the dance floor to make his way past a knot of people. He dances furiously for two second then steps down as THE DANCERS BEGIN TO SING "WOW", but j as the song breaks out musically, we hear the SOUND OF PE SHHHING; the singers falter and then stop as the party-go gather, in choreographed movement, at a ceiling mounted T set.

dialogues.speaker: MAN ON TV
dialogues.text: We can barely discern the words. . ."with his review is  Leonard Graff." A FRANTIC ACTRESS yelps a command:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't hear over this shhing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a play about guess what? That's  right, young people.

dialogues.speaker: ON MATT
dialogues.text: He stands next to a ruggedly handsome and extremely nause CONTEMPORARY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea, let's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to walk, the Handsome Contemporary falling into step. Everyone they pass is straining, upwards, at the TV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can we not listen to this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll know all we need to from the  reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment, the rest of the party-goers turn from the as one, looking mugged. (One girl briefly gets our attent because she is particularly distraught; tears streaming d her angry face. The mixture of tears and rage are, of cou the chemical components of incredible sexiness. Her name BETH.) A TORTURED MALE DANCER offers an incantation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should be shot, he should be dead,  he should rot in hell, then come  back as the soap cake in a urinal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to dancer) He didn't like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DIRECTOR moves through the group, bucking up spirits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. He doesn't count. We'll  just wait for the papers.

dialogues.speaker: ON MATT AND FELLOW CAST MEMBERS
dialogues.text: As they morosely watch the Director approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, no matter what this review says,  the play was a great experience for  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth looks at him, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) I mean, it is about process, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt's right. Good Lord, it is what  we're alive for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth turns from the conversation, finding it preposterous then rivets her attention on the Director, walking toward them, holding a ridiculously thick sheaf of papers. Beth  begins to sob in anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've just got to be tougher than  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Tougher than this?!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Director reaches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took it all down over the phone.  It's quite bad. And, unfortunately,  it's very, very long. I've got a  broken heart and writers' cramp.  He...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He savages everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear anymore. Let's  dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except you, Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fiercely to Matt) You filthy bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drawing closer to  Matt) What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Director hunts for the paragraph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please. You can't wait to run  out of here, buy a flashlight, and  then go into some dark alley and  drool over every word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (truthfully) You're wrong. I'm maybe relieved and  curious. That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wildly exasperated) What did they say about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) ...'in the midst of this delirium of  pretension...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't. This divisive crap won't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) '...one actor, rather miraculously,  manages to provide passion and, yes,  truth. Matt Hobbs, in the supporting  role of Jesus, manages to touch the  heart long after you thought it numbed  by boredom.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table of actors look at a sober Matt. A long beat and then, against his will, he grins... then a short, involun barking laugh of joy... then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his colleagues  with sincerity) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: L.A. MODERATE INCOME STREET
dialogues.text: As we HEAR the next lines of "WOW", BEGIN MAIN TITLES as CAMERA BOOMS UP to the outside of a small apartment as a  legend appears on screen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth, now 27, is standing in front of a TV set showing th Emmy dancers performing a phrase of "WOW". She screams ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you get in here--for God's sake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt, 30, is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Come on, Ma, how could I show up  tonight when my union is boycotting  the Emmys? Look, I have to hang up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming voice) It's on right now... right now...  right this second! You will miss  it!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) I gotta go. Watch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt hangs up and tear-asses into the living room. Beth  screams as his name is read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on TV) ...and Matt Hobbs for 'Caine Mutiny  Court Martial'... And the winner is  Powers Boothe for 'Jonestown--Story  of a Massacre.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! Fuck! Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) Shit! Shit! Shit! Fuck! Shit! Look,  he even showed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That took courage. I wonder if they  send you something for just being  nominated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of all the pathetic questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Why are you being so damn foul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth glares at him, on the verge of taking him on--but he looking at her very directly... the lack of any other age giving him a temporary edge... Beth decides to state the  unadorned truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been going back and forth on  our status for so long. I was hoping  that if you won, it might mean  something for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Beth... the only...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is waving her hand in a circle... he is puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please go fast. I can't take you  dragging it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit faster) The only reason I haven't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promised myself I wouldn't be so  bossy. Take your time!! Was that  bossy too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (persisting) The only thing I have against getting  married is that it might not be fair  because I'm going to stay with acting  forever and you know how erratic the  money's been and there's no resolve...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I get to vote? I'm going to tell  you something I never told you before.  Your feeling towards your work is  one of the things I love most about  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, then we have no problem here.  Marry me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss, then break, murmuring to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stinker, I almost gave up on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just worried whether I could  make you happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SET FRAME showing several clusters of waiting people. A man rushes to one of these clusters, cueing this group to sing the next phrase of "WOW". As an extremely hyper Matt enters, the SONG STOPS and a legend appears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extremely hyper) Everything's okay... Great... She's  six or eight pounds even. Oh, God...  Nothing like it. I'll tell you  something amazing. They really reach  right into her stomach and pull out  this baby. It's not just a rumor.  God. I understand the expression  'mind blowing' for the first time.  It means something so wonderful  happens that the top of your head  comes off and your brain pops out.  Part of it was terrifying, the baby  was turned and they couldn't budge  her. I kept looking at this one woman  doctor's eyes. And when Jeannie  finally came out, this doctor and I  each wiped away a tear at the exact  same time, caught ourselves doing  it, and then laughed together at the  same time. Nothing can prepare you  for it. You know why you're alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Matt walks with pep, accompanied by a burst of "WOW".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth holds BABY JEANNIE and wears a scowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doing? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother said you were flirting  with the doctor during the delivery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Matt's expression...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt and Beth lie on an open sofa-bed. "WOW" is completed though with a dirge-like cadence. We hear a baby crying o a cheap walky-talky near their bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you get her, honey? I have  that big reading tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I have a lot to do tomorrow,  too. I have to borrow on our Christmas  Club, I have to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about money anymore. (on her look) I didn't want to tell you, because  it may sound a little strange when I  say it out loud. You know me, I'm  never that cocky. But I'm going to  get 'Spider Woman'. It's me or Raul  and I've never been so sure. It's  weird, but I just know it. I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (broadly) Boy, am I reassured. What good news.  Isn't that a load off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where we see the crying baby holding the walky-talky in f of its mouth as it screams into the mouthpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am gonna get this part, Beth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stand this anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an awful place... the start-up apartment he's way to old for... but we don't yet see his humble quarters. Rath

dialogues.speaker: A BLURRED IMAGE
dialogues.text: Then, the screen is CLEARED ON ONE HALF so we see half of contact lens holder in focus--the other half blurred--unt Matt gets his second contact in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tube of tooth bleach. CLOSE ON THE DIRECTIONS, then:

dialogues.speaker: ON MATT
dialogues.text: Bleaching his teeth... finishing... smiling in the mirror This is the bleached smile of fear--true fear--the awful  state of having lost your way. The phone rings. Matt clea his voice before answering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello... Hi, Beth. I'm glad you  finally returned my call. What are  you so mad about? (again, into phone) YOU KNOW, YOU'RE NOT THE ONLY ONE  WHO CAN SCREAM, I CAN SCREAM, TOO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt was so suddenly, emotionally extended that the anger leaves him that quickly... just a strange atypical lightn bolt of rage toward life and women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again, into phone) You know what? I'm being a sort of  gutless wonder here. I'm yelling  back at you because I'm embarrassed.  I won't be able to take the kid when  I said... Why don't you listen for a  second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rubs his head with both hands, including the one holdi the phone. This allows us to hear his ex-wife repeat the  same sentence over and over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from phone) ...You're taking her... You're taking  her... You're taking her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth, I know exactly how long it's  been and I feel strange as hell not  seeing her but this isn't a choice.  I'm broke. It's the driest spell of  my life. I'm not saying it's your  problem, but it's no place for a six- year-old. What can I do? The only  full-time job I seem to have is not  showing how scared I am. What? No,  that's not something I said before. (accepting compliment) Well, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth turns angry again. Matt finds, unfortunately, that h got one more act of bravado left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again, into phone) Beth, Hey... hey. Never mind, I'll  do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again, to himself) I must get work. I will take anything.  I must get work. I must not be  embarrassed by these pep talks to  myself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Matt walks from the outdoor parking lot, past inexpens homes. In the lot, on private lawns and every public benc at each street corner, are various actors doing the relax exercises which will form the basis of A DANCE, as they g over their "sides".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...feathers I'm blowing. What am I,  a duck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pass various actors going over alternate sentences for the same speech so that we get a sense of the speech as a whole from the sum of its parts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1) I'm not thinking about whether  I'm going to shoot you. I'm... 2)...trying to decide where. 3)...the little spot behind the ear  where you die before you hear the  shot... 4)...on the left side of the belly  which is a very mean place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An office building of clear architectural merit located i an industrial area. Even the sign "Popcorn Pictures" has the artistic dignity the name itself lacks... MUSIC ENTER Gradually, movement BECOMES CHOREOGRAPHED...i.e., the you actor and actress running across the street do so with  uncommon grace. The area Matt passes is very crowded and still haven't reached the most congested area of all as w STUDY FACES and HEAR snatches of the actors' preparation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I, a duck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I'll tell you... Favor first...  Do a nice middle-aged lady a favor...  A fair trade... tell you what you  want to know in return for a... (grimaces over dialogue  she must say) ...a pity fu...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC BECOMING MORE INSISTENT as we approach the building the mumbling of the actors taking on the SOUND of a Waili Wall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the height of ego. You think your  he-manness can make me get on that  elevator even though I'm phobic?...  I CAN'T GET ON THAT ELEVATOR. I don't  care if... they catch us. DO YOU  GET... IT. DO YOU GET IT! I CAN'T! I  CAN'T... three, please.

dialogues.speaker: THREE HYSTERICAL ACTRESSES
dialogues.text: SINGING the dialogue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...can't get on the elevator... can't  get on the elevator... even if you  make me... even if you make me. Do  you get it?... do you get it?...

dialogues.speaker: TWO ACTRESSES
dialogues.text: Standing near each other--exchange glares as they break e other's concentration and move apart... THEIR MOVEMENT SE as our gateway to DANCING... The SONG "MAKE BELIEVE" ente fully now and builds in intensity, reaching a repeated ph as we move to Matt and he enters the building, thereby cu off the song.

dialogues.speaker: ON MATT
dialogues.text: As the SONG continues in intensity, Matt enters the build at the end of a repeated phrase cutting off the song as w move to:

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTION AREA
dialogues.text: Where CATHY BRESLOW, age 30, waits. Hollywood is a bit of uphill struggle for Cathy. She is bright where others are brilliant, pretty where others are gorgeous, enormously h working where others are obsessive-compulsive. She is cle waiting for someone while reading an enormously thick boo galley. Matt almost scoots by her, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi... See, I did recognize you. You  didn't have to wait for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I wanted to introduce you. As  if knowing me would help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING SHOT. Staircase packed with actors, an uphill slal almost impossible to navigate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a ridiculously awful movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, challenge. I wasn't sure you'd  remember me... let alone help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop. You're good. I'm doing them a  favor by getting you in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's a fresh slant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the casting assistant, CLAIRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire, this is Matt Hobbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Matt is handed a set of sides, we SHOOT PAST Matt as h watches Cathy move back down the stairs before he can say another word. She moves with wit. He is struck by her. He looks back at Claire, who has an intricate hairdo and a r smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Sorry. We're running behind...  Please forgive us.

dialogues.speaker: TWO HOURS LATER
dialogues.text: Her hairdo wilted, her blouse soiled, her smile gone, the tendons of her neck prominent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fiercely) Matt Hobbs? Matt Hobbs!

dialogues.speaker: ON MATT
dialogues.text: Going over his lines. Hearing his name, he rises. Claire  gestures him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walls are pockmarked with movie posters. THREE MEN si in an area some distance from the desk. The casting direc MARTIN, makes the introduction:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Matt Hobbs... This is John  Earl McAlpine, the director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He speaks with an Australian accent, gets half-up and ext his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and Burke Adler, the producer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what have you been doing with  yourself... (checking resume) ...the last few years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Burke) I'm real bad at interviews, so, if  you don't mind, I'd really prefer to  just read first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way you want to do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we shouldn't even read. I'll  just take your word that you're good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm serious. There's all different  ways. Did you know Woody Allen never  reads actors? He just looks at them,  feels around a little and then decides  who he wants. That's his way. Doesn't  hear them do a line. I also have a  way. What I do is interview first-- then read--maybe do it all over again  the next day. I call up people the  actor has worked with--check him  out. If he's famous, I do an opinion  survey to test how much people like  him. If he's not famous, I put him  on tape and show it to everyone I  can grab. I believe in screen tests;  I believe in replacing if the dailies  are bad, in cutting people out if  the previews aren't there. Because  I'm not doing movies for theaters  where they serve cappucino in the  lobby. I'm doing popcorn movies. You  want to know what I like? Come to my  house, look at my lamps... you won't  find it in my movies. In my movies,  you'll find out what I know. I know  how to do detail. What I don't know,  I discover. Yesterday we finished  mixing a movie--the last scene is in  a field of windmills which blows up  and all the blades of these windmills  slice through the air, one of which  hits a four-story tank of propane  gas. A humongous explosion scene. I  kept on saying 'louder', and they  finally said to me they couldn't go  louder without distortion. We went  louder. We had to discover a thing,  a filter, but we went louder. I don't  question doing these things. I do  them. So if you want to know if it's  okay to do it differently--not to  talk--to just read first... I say... (pointing to John  Earl) Ask him--he's the director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's do it. Do you have any  questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They only gave me these two pages.  I'd like to give this my best shot.  So if I could read the script and  come back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This part works tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Who will I be reading with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke indicates Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from his chair) Can I read from here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to do it wherever you're  comfortable, but I'd prefer it if  you were comfortable standing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt rises uncomfortably. A SECRETARY enters and hands a  note to the director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time for my buns to have visitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt looks astonished as the director leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Matt) Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead? The director left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, he trusts me, uh... And  we're just doing the first page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cueing him badly) 'Okay, darling Harry, here it is...  If someone were breaking up with me,  I'd like it short and sweet. What  about you?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading--showing  pain) 'Incredibly drawn out...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'I can't take care of you right now.  What am I, your mother?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intense) 'Well, what am I? Your duck?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he gets into the scene he begins to experience some re of the desperate feelings he's been harboring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) 'We've been together two years and  you act like all you're doing is  blowing away some feathers. So what  I'm asking...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't do the quack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stage direction says for him to  quack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but why would he quack when  someone's breaking up with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopefully because it's funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a comedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we're in trouble, because they're  already fall down laughing at the  teaser-trailer in fifty-two hundred  and thirty theaters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A comedy? (rubbing his face) I think I have to make an adjustment  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR the strains of the theme of a past hit movie comi from Cathy's cassette player. A rack of soundtracks clear visible. Cathy is frowning as she reads the last of the g pages. She overhears some conversation in the adjoining r which begins to disturb her concentration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not supposed to read TV pilots.  Don't call us D-Girls. We're  Development Persons!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy closes the door, shutting her off. She now begins t fill out a form with a felt-tipped pen. As she does so, t pad is supered on the screen--action seen through it. As writes, we see the notations on the super. It is marked COVERAGE--CONFIDENTIAL FROM: CATHY BRESLOW. BURKE ADLER. SUBJECT: (the pen writes out) "LITTLE DICK"  GENRE/CATEGORY (the pen writes out ACTION-ADVENTURE). The there are columns to check EXCELLENT, GOOD, FAIR, POOR fo the story. CHARACTERS, DIALOGUE... The pen checks FAIR fo story, POOR for all else, CHARACTER, DIALOGUE, etc. The f then states--CHECK ONE OF THE FOLLOWING SENTENCES:

dialogues.speaker: I'D GLADLY STAKE MY ALL ON THIS PROJECT
dialogues.text: The phone rings. As she picks it up and reaches to turn d the volume of the motion picture soundtrack she's listeni to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hi. I just finished. I'll have my  coverage right over. It's past  derivative... it's photocopying.  What a hoot! You're kidding, right?  There is truly active bidding for  this book? Really? 2.3 million? Okay,  see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up and begins to alter the form changing the  STORY/POOR to STORY/EXCELLENT, and all the other POORS to GOOD... and now the Recommend section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pen is poised.

dialogues.speaker: ON CATHY
dialogues.text: Her soul is poised. A beat and she allows "I DO NOT RECOM to stand, the source music theme--"CHARIOTS OF FIRE"-- coincidentally celebrates this considerable act of herois Cathy takes the sheet and walks to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she approaches her secretary's desk, she overhears two other members of Burke's Development Staff (a 27-year-old well-dressed man and a woman younger than Cathy) as they  enthuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even the title "Little Dick"--it  means so many things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Story, story, story, story, story. (seeing Cathy) You loved it, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had some problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know, it's a little  garbagey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it has to be cast right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Cathy doesn't like it, we know  it's a smash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stung) Hey. It's not like I didn't recommend  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She surreptitiously changes her "recommend" as Matt enter She looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get it. He did say something  about wanting me back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. His saver is he means what he  says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just wanted to say thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods and starts to turn back towards her office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and I wanted to ask you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other people in the office stare at Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns) For when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never know when I'm free. (Matt nods) It sounds like I'm just... but it's  true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Thanks again. I felt funny  asking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant asking you to get me the  audition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... well, don't please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods and starts to go. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt smiles in astonishment and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I was auditing this acting course  and he filled in teaching one night.  He did a scene himself and he was  awesome. For some reason, he can't  get arrested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He does seem to have a layer  of loser dust on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt drives his faded, seven-year-old car into view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks off... sees something that arrests his interest pulls to the curb. It's a curious sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke Adler, standing at a street corner, palpably in pai He's trying to rein in his emotions, sucking in huge gulp of air... and, then, a wave of emotion gets the better of him as he looks at his watch. A sob escapes him--shocked  that he's so close to tears on a public street corner, he battles for control... another sob as he looks to the hea

dialogues.speaker: ON MATT
dialogues.text: A split second to consider, then he's out of his car.

dialogues.speaker: THE STREET CORNER
dialogues.text: A flow of PEOPLE--in the foreground, the tortured figure Burke Adler--in the background, Matt Hobbs, pauses before intruding. But Burke's spectacle is growing more public,  sounds of anguish escape him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God... why? Why?... (louder) What am I going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now he begins to dissassemble, openly crying--on the  verge of a complete breakdown. Matt moves into frame, gra Burke, trying to provide him with an anchor.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: His face--his eyes providing a beacon of strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Hey! HEY!!

dialogues.speaker: ON BURKE
dialogues.text: Totally fucked-up, wild-eyed. As he witnesses his own sta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me. You'd think I was a  writer. (his story of travail  pours from him) I hired this kid as a production  assistant. His father's a business  manager... a few good clients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been driving for me two weeks...  all he has to do is pick me up on  time... he's twenty minutes late and  I have a test screening in the valley.  Everybody's gone from the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke flails at himself as Matt looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that it? You need a lift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm right over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt starts to lead him back, then realizes he's alone, B having seen his car finally arrive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, berating the YOUNG DRIVER. Matt pauses, awed by th wild gesticulating--the few screamed words...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Not just today... believe me,  there's no way you'll ever make it...  You are going to fail. Listen, listen-- I know about this; you are going to  be a failure.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA FOLLOWING MATT
dialogues.text: As he joins Burke and the young man, Burke turns to Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Matt) Let's get moving; you said you'd  give me a lift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about?  Not in your car... I've got my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you a hundred and twenty  dollars to take me... and it will  still be a favor. (to Young Man) Get out. Come on. (to Matt) Please. This is very important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (final plea) A guy got shot on the freeway...  Traffic's tied up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should leave time for that kind  of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you need me for? Don't you  drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a mumble) Yeah, I drive. I don't like to look  for parking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun setting on a nondescript slab of California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men... Matt feeling very peculiar in this line of work. Burke's tension renders him arresting, handsome eve The look of generals who go forth against long odds. He t an enormous cleansing breath. It startles Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explaining) Yoga shit. I feel like barbed wire.  I don't know if you keep track, but  I'm the sixth independent producer  ever to have two big pictures  scheduled for Christmas, and tonight  we're testing the first one for the  first time... You get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's important to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing at the  understatement) Yes. I don't think I would have put  it that way... but, yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke's car moves toward the movie complex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our first view of NAN MULHANNEY; middle-aged and pragmati yet extraordinarily naive. She's a scientist of sorts-- monitoring the tastes and feelings of Americans, first in Washington and now here. Though she just had a very rough hour or so, she bends down to smile at Burke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep driving. She runs the test  screenings. Very smart. Very. She  has a real case on me, but so far  I've been keeping it in the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops talking, stops breathing, as he sees.

dialogues.speaker: THE TEST AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: The line consists of disparate, disinterested people who focused on their own small, personal dramas--not at all  cognizant of the fact that they hold a life in their hand They are clearly growing impatient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go very slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC IN... Burke steels himself and exits the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're 34 minutes late. The studio is  appropriately wild... people are  beginning to leave... but I knew how  upset you'd be if we started without  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distantly) Yeah. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he pays her no mind as MUSIC CONTINUES and he moves  towards the line. Nan approaches the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is he tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know him, so I have nothing  to compare it to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how would you say he is, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite himself.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: As he approaches the line, he BEGINS TO SING his love to  them, "I'll Do Anything." As he pours out his misdirected heart to individuals on the line who DO NOT HEAR HIM.

dialogues.speaker: LINE
dialogues.text: Their impatience gives rise to a VERY SLOW TAP DANCE, eac couple or cluster doing it differently--barely exaggerati the normal shifting of a line... As BURKE CONTINUES TO SI the song builds as does the dance... Burke sings even mor passionately, his D-PEOPLE perhaps joining in as BACKGROU SINGERS. At a key point, the disparate groups turn and fo a SOLID UNIFIED LINE. They begin the rhythmic clapping of impatience--having become a line, they now threaten to be a mob. Burke sings one more Joe Cocker-like passionate pl before turning to camera to shout over the mayhem:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let them in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nan is addressing the audience from down front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name of the picture you'll be  seeing is 'Ground Zero'... There may  be some scratches... some of the  colors may be off, there are no final  titles, and it has not been finally  mixed for sound, and the music is  temp, that means temporary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she says this:

dialogues.speaker: REAR OF HOUSE
dialogues.text: Where Burke spies the STUDIO HEAD and leaves Matt's side.

dialogues.speaker: ON STUDIO HEAD
dialogues.text: As BURKE enters the frame behind him. He is right behind boss' ear. He leans in and offers an intimacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you came yourself instead  of sending your staff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boss is startled--jumps. BURKE eyes him... there must some way to profit from these stolen moments with a power man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be surprised if tonight's  screening is a monster. (emphatically) Could happen, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves back to Matt and Nan at the rear of the audience

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Matt) Eisner just said he thinks the  screening will be a monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strangely, Burke seems truly buoyed by the words of  encouragement he himself manufactured. He moves down thre rows and sits in an aisle seat just as the film opens wit series of violent explosions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, God, let tonight give him  peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incredibly, Burke turns and gestures to her that the soun of her small voice is interfering with the cacophony of h movie. Nan is clearly stricken by her lapse as she whispe to Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're short two card-counters, can  you two help out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are seeing one of the final moments of the film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the muscular hero moves with stealth through the giant refrigerated meat door. He passes cows and dead men hangi from alternate hooks. Suddenly, he is attacked by the vil brandishing an electric meat dismembering tool. The hero  ducks, the machine ripping apart hanging cow flesh. The h grabs the only weapon he can find: a large piece of meat a large bone, which he uses as a mace. He clubs the other man--then again--and again. Part of the audience is whoop and applauding.

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: Standing with Matt and Cathy. At the sound of the applaus Nan grins and mumbles with a connoisseur's knowledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Males, fifteen and under.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCREEN
dialogues.text: Where the hero stands over the man whose face he has  shattered, holding a club from which hang strings of meat He is breathing heavily, and between breaths, states:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to bust your chops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General audience laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'll just stay in your seats a  few moments and fill out these cards  for us...

dialogues.speaker: ON AISLES
dialogues.text: Matt and others handing out cards with pencils attached.. Folks filling them out. As an ADOLESCENT MALE fills it ou PREVIEW CARD FILLS THE SCREEN as we view LIVE ACTION THRO IT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An office meant for two, containing twenty counters. The  counting is done with erasers rifling stacks, creating a  sound, a MUSICAL RHYTHM, as the GROUP CAPTAIN calls out w gospel cadence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who has young males? Young women?  Older males?... Older males?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt, his tally finished, squats on the floor, waiting. T Group Captain approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Older males... older males?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt looks blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) Older males... over 25?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt now realizes that it is his category and hands over older male cards and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, prowling the lobby as audience stragglers leave an Studio Execs and Popcorn Development Staff wait. He looks off to see Matt and Nan chatting in another part of the l

dialogues.speaker: ON MATT AND NAN
dialogues.text: As they arrive... Nan looks off to see the Group Captain  approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long since you've seen your  daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little over two years. (on her look) My wife insisted on moving back to  the Midwest--then I was in the  Philippines on the mini-series and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly and loudly) Oh, please. It's one thing being a  son-of-a-bitch, but you don't have  to be a stupid son-of-a-bitch. People  move heaven and earth to see their  kids. I don't care if she moved to  Pluto, it's abandonment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause, then) Hey, we just met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing) Oh. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make a guess how we did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't mean anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing good that happens can make  it worth feeling the way I do now.  Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OLDER WOMAN approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you? This is private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Mr. Eisner's mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Can I get you some water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Group Captain approaches and hands Nan a sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone, all the studio and Popcorn staff, is drawn to N

dialogues.speaker: ON NAN
dialogues.text: As she glances at the figures.

dialogues.speaker: ON NAN'S LEFT HAND
dialogues.text: As she secretly reaches for and holds Burke's hand. Is it sympathy or congratulations?

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON STUDIO EXECUTIVE FACES
dialogues.text: As we see in ever-so-SLOWED ACTIONS, tense lips turning  gloriously upward to reveal gums--then a smile. More smil as we pan across teeth... bonded executives and bonded te The shot widens. The studio head mumbles to himself as he carefully goes over the tally in every category. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need the numbers. I loved  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His smiling face takes us:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, ninety in the top two boxes.

dialogues.speaker: TO BURKE
dialogues.text: A tear in his eye--a smile shyer than others. He turns to the old lady, instinctively using this victory to settle most recent score as he says mockingly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now can I get you some water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy and Matt are leaning against Burke's car. Cathy is  distraught--temporarily, but horribly, unsure of herself. Matt is looking at her. If he had a little more confidenc going for him right now, he would make his move. But, for now, they are two self-doubters on different trips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought it would do this  well. There were so many holes; I  told everybody it wasn't going to do  business. Why am I so public with my  opinions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might be right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not with that score. You know, maybe  tonight's the night I'm losing my  entire mind, but weren't you in  'Platoon?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incredible. I was only there for a  minute in the rape scene, moving  past Charlie Sheen when I left the  hut... I had a great scene cut out...  I was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there was that one long close up-- where you seemed ashamed of yourself  but still arrogant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly what I was going for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It reminded me of my last boyfriend. (indicating book bag) Got to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hefts the bag--puts it back down--crosses her eyes,  burlesquing the weight of the bag. He helps her put it on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to read all that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beast of burden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sincerely) So what are you, totally wonderful  or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles and is gone, staggering a bit under the weight her scripts. Matt looks after her. Burke and Nan approach

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you haven't said anything?  This is great, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The definite recommends are way off  for a score this high and, even for  action-adventure, it's just too low  for women. (Burke looks anguished) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans against the car for support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was such a good score.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extraordinarily  sympathetic) I know... And, unfortunately,  yesterday's tracking wasn't... (he reacts) I'm sorry... They just don't seem in  the mood for action-adventure right... (he reacts) Sorry... May I tell you one more  thing? (he looks up in  anticipatory fear) I think it's so wonderful that you  don't worry about even trying to act  strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. You want to eat something  sometime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm, uh... I'm blushing from head to  foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. I'll call you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Burke moves to his car. He SEES the Group Captain payi Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-two, thirty-three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke is looking at Matt with some surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to do this regularly for  me? I was gonna offer, but I thought  it would humiliate you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straight at him) I don't mind an occasional odd job.  But I can't work tomorrow. I have to  get my kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they get in the car, Burke has the front door open, ab to get in--reconsiders, and gets in the rear door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I got the cards to look at--I  think I'll ride back here. (to Nan) Maybe I'll drop by your place  tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt gets behind the wheel, thereby ending the day as a f fledged chauffeur. They drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Nan returning from lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, thanks for lunch. I hope this  leads to an evening date. Though I  have to stay home with my daughter,  Leslie, on Saturdays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sincerely) Yeah, okay. You were very interesting  to talk to. I swear to God. Honest.  No kidding. You really were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you. (sincerely) And I was very surprised what you  were like when you weren't working.  There was absolutely no difference.  You want to see where we do the  tracking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) Is it okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The enter the room containing a maze of telephone cubbies with workers manning the phones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody ever wants to see how we do  the polling, but they're like little  starved puppies when the data comes  in--running at you, scrambling to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke hardly hears. He is awed as if by a cathedral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1) How often do you go to the movies? 2) I'm going to describe a movie in  one sentence and then ask you to  rate it on a scale of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as the workers  continue) I love this. This is what counts and  this is where you count it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft and true) That's the same way I feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You phone all over--you know what  movies they're waiting to see, whether  your TV spots are working. You know  what the country thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...what feelings do you have about  Cher as a singer, an actress, or  potential date...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) ...and it's accurate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Within six-point-eight percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you can't fix it... right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... no... Sometimes just for myself,  I can't resist asking America a  personal question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) When do you feel more worthless-- mornings or afternoons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pause by a workers to say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assume Michelle Pfeiffer is the woman-- which of these 67 actors would you  most like to see her with... Patrick  Swayze, Keanu Reeves, Dustin Hoffman,  Johnny Dep, the guy from 'Major  Dad'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something I meant to tell  you. You may have noticed something  unusual about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could never find the right time  to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this urgent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe not urgent, but  immediately significant and necessary  to tell. (a deep breath) You see, there's these pills...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I gotta go. I'm listening  with an eighth of an ear now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits as the telephone pollster continues with the lis of prospective Michelle Pfeiffer male co-stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt, wearing earphones, is in the middle of a row of fiv intent on what he is watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A recent example of a great actor in a regular movie...  something like Brando in "The Freshman." No sound.

dialogues.speaker: ON MATT
dialogues.text: Watching intently. Not watching--studying... not studying fully appreciating. Now he sees a particularly good momen looks around joyously for half a beat--a reflex to share  what he saw. His neighbors, not quite knowing what he's  smiling at; he returns his attention to the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Matt's cab pulls up. He opens the front gate and walks to the porch, noting a tricycle, stirred by old guilts. H knocks on the door. A MAN answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Matt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know if we could wait much  longer. Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lights a cigarette, takes three quick drags, then flic it away before walking inside behind Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) She's a real nut on smoking anywhere  near the kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter. A bedroom down a narrow hallway from where th stand. Remember "The Best Years of Our Lives"... Frederic March coming home from the wars and seeing his wife just beat before she sees him. Here we have a wretched mutant that moment. Beth, still fierce and attractive, is packin her daughter's suitcase when she senses him and looks up. Shaking her head with a disapproval which will never die, she walks to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello--did you two meet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. Is she ready? I have the  taxi waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just have to say goodbye. You have  no idea how difficult that is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several beats--Beth and the man staring at Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not taking her for a visit.  You are taking her for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because you want to go off with  him doesn't mean I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting the wrong idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so. No matter how you  put this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look, I'm a United States  Marshal. I'm here because she didn't  show up yesterday to start serving  her time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a choice. You don't  have a choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and starts for the other room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning) I loved, helped and supported in  every possible way a business man  who committed the terrible crime of  being financially imaginative with a  pension fund.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits. He sits down, stunned in the headlights of his fate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt and the Marshal in the foreground as Beth talks to  Jeannie in the background. We see only glimpses of them.  Beth's face as she leans towards Jeannie from one side of the doorway--just Jeannie's legs dangling on the other si

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, listen carefully, Jeannie. Be  still. Now, what's the most important  thing in life to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one will ever love me as much as  you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt and the Marshal exchange a look of mutual horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Now, concentrate with all your  muscles and remember everything I'm  about to say to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Marshal and Matt shift uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to strangers. They may be  killers. Take your vitamins so the  poison in the food can't hurt you.  What else now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Thank you. Brush right after  you eat or your gums will start to  bleed in your sleep and choke you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Marshal and Matt can stand no more--they each call to her... "Beth... Beth... Mrs. Hobbs... Beth." She looks ou and then walks to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I'm giving Jeannie her  reminders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reminders?!? You can't say things  like that to a little...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Don't. No. Don't dare. Don't  criticize the way I mother or I think  I'll start to scream and never st...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hobbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly cheery) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I've been involved with  this sort of thing for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to criticize me,  are you? Not in front of him--because  all he's done is send Jeannie these  long, stupid letters. He doesn't  even realize she can't read. He sends  letters to someone who can't read. (laughs) It's almost funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd read them to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not faulting you. You love your  daughter and this is a very tough  thing to go through. You feel guilty  and caring and it all gets mixed up  so that there's so much important  stuff going down that there's no  sure way of dealing with it, but the  best thing you can do is just make  sure you love her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Typical cop talk. (on his look) But I understand what you're trying  to say. Thank you. Can I have another  minute with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She returns to the doorway which still only provides us w glimpses as she SINGS, "DON'T TALK TO STRANGERS." The CAM MOVES down the hallway to INTRODUCE JEANNIE, trying to pu things out as she sits amongst a ridiculous number of  suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the two females who bear his name approach. Matt doesn want a pregnant first moment with Jeannie, so he wards of silence with chatter. Unfortunately, he can only think of one word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, hi, hi, hi, hi, hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing mirthlessly) Hello, monster-poop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to U.S. Marshal) She has her mother's sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth stops him with a look, then bends down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, love, Mommy's going to help  others who need her for a few years,  and you're going with Daddy as I  explained. (to Marshal and Matt) We'll all have to help with the  luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All three adults and Jeannie sharing the burden of the lu as they move towards the cab. Mother and child hug. Matt  struck by his child's plight, him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Matt) Beginning now, you must give less  value to your own happiness and well- being, then hopefully, you will reach  the point where you give that no  value whatsoever. Give her everything.  There's no such thing as spoiling a  child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if you have to steal to do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't really want to mess with  me, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simple honesty) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jeannie) Okay, sweetie. We have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Beth) I want to go with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't, pretty-heart. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears fall from Jeannie's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even a compromise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking) The compromise will be that you don't  have to ride in back; you can ride  up front with the driver... okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Beth buckles Jeannie into the front seat, Matt gets in the back, alone, feeling preposterous. Beth nods to the  Marshal, who surreptitiously handcuffs her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to driver) Can we please go?

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: The cab pulls away. Matt leans towards her as she looks b at the receding figure of her mother and grows still.

dialogues.speaker: ON MOTHER AND MARSHALL
dialogues.text: As she sings him one last line of "DON'T TALK TO STRANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt checks Jeannie's luggage, then takes her hand. She l him. He is grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be okay. I'm you're  dad, you know? So it will be okay.  You and I will make it okay. You  ever ridden in a plane before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a sudden gust of  anger) Yesssss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie and Matt in the center two seats of a five seat r Jeannie is coloring in a book which Matt bought her; he i holding some extra crayons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't stare at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to put on my yellow dress  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's underneath the plane. We can't  get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just that quick, Jeannie screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to put on my dress. I want to  put on my dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other passengers turn around. This is pretty raw stuff we into. Temper in all its wildness, MUSIC UNDER... electric guitar beginning to match the energy and naked emotion of the child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no way we can get the dress-- it's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie's feet start kicking in front of her--the person that seat turning sharply around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't kick the seat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want the yellow dress. (a shriek) Give me a compromise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is crying now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as we land. That's the  compromise.

dialogues.speaker: MORE MUSIC
dialogues.text: Without warning, Jeannie slaps herself in the face. All f people in the row ahead turn and say in unison:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't hit her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I didn't hit her--she hit her.

dialogues.speaker: LIGHTS
dialogues.text: As everyone starts pushing the cabin attendant call butto These dings magnify until they're part of the music--as i drives and drives... Matt takes Jeannie's hand and tries restrain her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noooooo. Let go of me. Noooo. The  yellow dress... let go... let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She breaks away from him. He moves after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At breakneck speed, Jeannie dashes through the plane with her father in pursuit... flashes of disapproving faces. T seat belt sign goes on. A FLIGHT ATTENDANT blocks his pat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie takes advantage of Matt's being stopped and moves into the toilet, locking the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Jeannie, we have to sit down. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be having some turbulence for  the next twenty minutes or so. Will  the cabin attendants please take  their seats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply and utterly) I have no idea what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sudden bump and Matt falls. He yells to the locked door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie, you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to your seat. I'll get her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Matt makes his way back, the Flight Attendant uses a h latch to open the door. Music building--then calming, the worst is over. Matt makes his way back to his seat, shell shocked. The Attendant leans over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants to be alone. So we're  upgrading her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the aisle--Jeannie lets an Attendant lead her as she peers back at her dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt carrying the sleeping child like a sack over his  shoulder, also managing to hold onto all her luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has propped her on the sofa, a cotton nightgown out. H is unbuttoning her dress. She opens her eyes, the window' protective bars PLACING A SHADOW ACROSS HER FACE. She att to cover her fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the wrong jammies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... so what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie mimics him perfectly under her breath. She goes t an open suitcase and throws things on the floor until she finds the right jammies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do I sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a sleeping bag and bed. Which  one do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She surveys her pitiful choice; then points to the sleepi bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets into it. He zips her up--then she says something remarkably unexpected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazed, Matt hugs her. A half-beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does--then stands and looks down at her. She looks bac mocking his stare with one of her own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nan uncertainly enters this decidedly masculine bathroom. She is wearing an evening gown. The sun streams through t lush foliage outside a wall-sized window. MUSIC as she op her purse and removes a pillbox; at one point lightly sin a snatch of lyric concerning the conflicts of being a sin woman and a single mother--this while totally focused on pills.

dialogues.speaker: PILL BOX
dialogues.text: A major movie shot of this compartmentalized box. Each  burrowed nest clearly labeled for the pill it contains:

dialogues.speaker: ON NAN
dialogues.text: MUSIC CONTINUES. She dials a phone number while arching h neck and swallowing one pill after another with little sw of water. This process continuing, even as she speaks int the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monica--is Leslie up yet? Good. I  didn't want you to get worried when  you realized I wasn't there. I'm  still with that man. I'll tell you  about it later. But it's sure nice  to have wobbly legs again. Look,  today's recycling day for Leslie at  school, so give her some empty cans...  well, then dump some out for her!  Tell her I had to leave real early  for work and I'll pick her up at  school myself to make up for it and  we'll rent any cassette she wants  for tonight. Thank you... Take good  care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up. Another snatch of lyric as she bends to bru her teeth with her finger; prepares herself and opens the door to greet her new lover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke sits on the edge of the bed, fearful. He sees her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I thought you took off in the  middle of the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves quickly to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I just had to call home. Is that  why you're sad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's Everett. This kid who used  to work for me. He was always crazy  to do his own movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fearing worst) What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very down) His movie not only opened to a three  million dollar Friday--it's gotten  great reviews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nan is dumbfounded; still she puts a hand on him, actuall consoling him for his hideous thought--Hollywood lovers: wrapped up with ill thoughts of others; she, feeling inti yet severely compromised. Cupid's work is done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) Listen. I'm tremendously worried  about 'Ground Zero' because of the  bad 'want to sees' you sent over.  But that's just me being nervous  over nothing, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's just you correctly  assessing the situation. So stop  being so hard on yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He eyes her, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a muffled argument between Matt and Jeannie comin from inside their apartment. Then the door opens and Matt holding Jeannie by the hand, moves down the hall to the n door and knocks. (NOTE: Jeannie is dressed in layers of v clothing--some of the layers play clothes, some fit for a coronation. She is a pocket contemporary Annie Hall... he style so much her own it transcends judgement. Her hair i unkempt. The door opens revealing Lucy, an Hispanic woman her mid-30s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're you doing? I'm from next door.  I see you with your kids in the  laundry room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. (seeing Jeannie, turns  warmer) ...Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie is a bit shy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, 'Hello, I'm your new neighbor  now too.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Lucy Crisala... What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, 'Jeannie.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The form of the conversation is forged. Jeannie not answe anything. Matt bending over to Jeannie while he forms her answers to Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a little girl too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, 'Isn't that nice... How old is  she?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's four and a half and I have a  little boy who is not yet one year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, 'That's nice... I'd like to  play with them... My Daddy didn't  know your phone number, so we just  decided to...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say 'Daddy has to go to work tonight  and...' (catching himself and  looks directly at  Lucy) I need someone to help me and her on  short notice. I've seen your around  with your kids and hoped you knew  someone in the building or close by.  I've got this new job that starts  now. Do you know anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm always here. I could maybe  do it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (there is a God and a  good one at that) Oh, this is so great. Let's work out  a full-time schedule and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. Jeannie, why don't you come in  for a minute and meet Ricky and Essa.  Come on, we're making fruit bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie walks into the apartment past her father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again, to Matt) Why don't you leave her for a while  and then we talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort of a test?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll just see how it works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play-pen in the middle of the floor... Jeannie stands the staring at Essa who is playing with her little brother. M moves to embrace Jeannie who cranes away from him. He sta with it, whispering in her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please behave, understand? I don't  know what we'll do if this doesn't  work, so behave, sweetheart. Behave,  behave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he exits towards his own apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt is extraordinarily anxious. Then he HEARS loud cryin and screaming from next door. There is a stab of despair. Matt deflates, then resigned, exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of screaming now louder. He walks to Lucy's doo takes a breath and knocks. The door opens and Lucy stands there looking rattled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I bothered you. (calling inside) Jeannie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I have her a little bit longer?  My little boy just fell and Jeannie  is the only one he let hold him.

dialogues.speaker: ON MATT
dialogues.text: A devil's weight lifted from his shoulders. The slap-happ smile of the just saved plastered on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your little boy fell, so he's  screaming. And you want her to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, confused by his buoyant reaction, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Seven dollars an hour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Thank you. See you later,  Jeannie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to kiss her, but she shuns him. Lucy, now having official status, turns to admonish her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's okay. I'm fine with it. I  feel fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke walks tight little circles near Cathy and the rest his staff while a few feet away Studio Executives stand i cluster. There is a DISTANT, RHYTHMIC SHUFFLING SOUND. Bu walks past Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing good that happens tonight  can make it worth feeling the way I  do right now. Nothing. (turning to Cathy) What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously taking the  plunge) To be honest, I had problems with  'Ground Zero.' But this 'People Get  Hurt' one, while it might not be my  exact, exact thing, I think will  really work for an audience. It's so  over the top, you have a great time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you think it'll score big?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where we discover the SOURCE OF THE SOUND. Some twenty ca counters on the floor riffling through stacks of cards wi erasers. Matt and Nan stand in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. My daughter used to  throw fits in supermarkets when we  first moved here. It's all so  perfectly normal. Plus I know a great  psychiatric children's group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what breaks your heart.  Jeannie's problem is that she's so  down on herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she's lucky to have a daddy  who cares, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if lucky's the word.  I'm hoping she's asleep when I get  home so I won't have to deal with  her... I'm actually afraid of my own  kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my. I've had exactly that feeling  and never said it out loud. See,  there are men who talk my language  and I'm just cursed that I'm not  attracted to them because they are  so nice they remind me of myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt laughs. In the b.g., the counting is completed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very goods?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a second... (finishes counting) 666.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Group Captain notes the figure on a sheet, walks to t doorway and hands it to Nan, who is still deep into  conversation with Matt. She begins walking back to the th without looking at the sheet in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I felt terrible about the way I blew  up at you when I first met you. (before he can object) Please.

dialogues.speaker: THEATER AREA
dialogues.text: Burke and others waiting as Matt and Nan come to a stop s distance away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I began taking anti-depressants when  we moved here from Washington. I had  some small reactions--sleeping 14  hours, no libido, I gained 17 pounds  in nine days--that sort of thing. So  they gave me pills to deal with the  side effects. And then pills to deal  with the side effects I was getting  from those pills. All this besides  the stuff the nutritionist was giving  me. The combination formed some sort  of potion so that I keep telling the  truth. I don't have a choice. That's  why I was so rude to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your doctor says this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. He's excited, but only  because he sees glory for himself in  it... See, ordinarily I wouldn't say  that about my doctor, but I can't  help it, it's the truth. He's  monitoring me for a while longer  before writing it up for this medical  journal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy has joined them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke's going crazy waiting for the  score.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
