dialogues.text: (to Matt) How are you, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt shifts, figuring out his answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a small laugh) It's a tough one, huh? Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nan looks down at the score.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my. Matt, I'd better drive him  myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts for Burke.

dialogues.speaker: ON BURKE AND OTHERS
dialogues.text: As Nan arrives and hands the Studio Executives the score, Burke looking over their shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can fix this... Get some narration  written. . . (turning to Director) You'll cut 30 minutes. It will come  out like butter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're only 77 minutes now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling to himself) ...a 47-minute movie... no, that  won't work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go. I have a nanny problem.  Priorities, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses his cheek and leaves. A beat of silence... Bur turns to Nan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) Can you help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly the moment Nan has been waiting for... she does h a valuable observation to offer at this dark moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopeful) Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only a movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Burke looks at her from the depths of his pain and see her confidently believing that she has imparted something value, the movie's marquee lights go off giving us a:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he carries an enormously resistant Jeannie, wearing a  borrowed T-shirt nightie, back towards his apartment... M has Jeannie under one arm--her clothes and shoes in anoth Jeannie's arms are extended towards Lucy, who stands in t open doorway of her apartment. She begins thrashing. Gian tears come--the moment is operatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go. Please, Lucy, don't make me  go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's tired. You can come back  tomorr...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Jeannie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to live here with these people.  God, let me live here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

Hey, I know everyone thinks I don't  have any commercial sense because of  what I said at the 'Gremlins' preview  and all... And you think I can't put  myself on the line. Well, if this  picture doesn't work, fire me. Have  me killed if it doesn't get good  reviews. If this doesn't get a 70  percent definite recommend from women  49 and under, I promise to be your  sex slave until they drop ticket  prices back to five bucks and start  enforcing the R rating.

Jeannie sings along with the child's chorus on the tape,  "YOU COULD BE WONDERFUL", making, with little hand motion the last thing Matt needs, but, in due course, he starts actually make a bit of transitional progress out of his o troubles and into the fact that his daughter is beguiling But, before the mood can fully sweeten, Jeannie forgets t lyrics and begins to verbally assault herself as the tape continues to play...

Cathy, uncomfortable in these surroundings, parks her car, brushes her hair, while, at the same time, putti in place a phony cheap-car-radio-sticker over her own  expensive system, and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop being so creepy honest. I really  have an instinct about you for this.  I'm going home--call me when you  finish reading it. (how quickly status  changes things) Or... come on over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoops. Tell me what made you rush  over and pick me up and bring me  here at six o'clock. I mean we seem  to have...

dialogues.text: (again) ...this unspoken agreement not to  talk about why we're together when  we're together and I don't think  it's good to let that become a pattern  for us.

That you seem to have lapsed into  some final cynicism, where you  actually believe that, not only does  everyone think the way you do, but  only you have the courage to express  it? That you seem horribly certain  everyone else is sort of pretending  when they talk about love or seem to  care for anything outside their own  anus? No one's ever said that sort  of thing to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.text: She twists toward the phone again--not quite so beautiful

Scorsese didn't get the Time cover,  the plane crash did... ha, ha, ha...  Why aren't you at the office? You  know, I'm getting to the point where  I prefer to reach people's machines...  Bye.

What did you think? That makes  two bombs in a row for her. (into phone) ...four, five, six... Pick up if  you're there. I've got major gossip...  major screwup. It could be good for  us.

Don't even  give hints that there's something  you can't tell them, but you wish  you could... I'm losing it. I'm losing  it. I'm losing it. Don't tell nobody.  Don't tell nobody. Don't tell nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: How many men are they testing today?

dialogues.text: Matt is surprised... But he is a pro and so immediately m use of this sudden blip in status.

dialogues.text: Then tell them I need a little more  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's okay, we're done.

dialogues.text: I mean for me. I want to focus a  little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. (she hugs Matt) Good luck, Matt. (whispered advice) The thing they're looking for most  is sexy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then they're gone. With that bit of advice, Matt is  totally fucked up. A beat after Cathy leaves:

dialogues.text: You know who she was involved with  for a minute or so?

dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On their look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) You guys have to leave. This is  important and I need to be alone  right now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit... Matt thumbs through the script... does a  relaxation exercise... takes a breath and thinks... a bea and he is reasonably confident... he walks one half-circl of the room making sure he's fully pumped, then exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As crowded as it was for the previous audition scene, but this time they are reading children of varied ages, and t kids and their parents are all over the stairs, etc. Jean is filled with wonder and is arrestingly and atypically s as she makes her way through this world of the young, cli to Cathy's hand, as the kids sing their version of "MAKE  BELIEVE"--the stage parents taking one verse. At one poin Cathy's begins talking to someone, blocking Jeannie's vie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of my way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say it like that!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way should I? (polite little girl) Get out of my way. (almost weeping) Get out of my way. (furious) Get out of my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this noticed by a casting person with a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It felt great... Everybody...

dialogues.text: Let me tell him, let me tell him,  let me tell him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie turns down her volume, but keeps repeating--incan actually... "I can't wait to tell him... I can't wait to  tell him... I can't wait to tell him..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, the girl I did it with, by  the way, she's really good; the  director, the crew... they all thought  we nailed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loving, sexy) Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cathy) Now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy nods and Jeannie begins to push Matt into Cathy's o for privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait till you hear this one.

dialogues.text: Jeannie sits her father down. This is the first time we'v seen her joyful. Pure glee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some lady asked me to go in a room  and, you know, make believe and say  stuff like we were playing a game...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words coming so fast that Jeannie lets loose with a b of SONG, as if taking a moment to catch her breath. Just few sung lines proclaiming happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) And everybody went 'yea' and they  said they wanted me to be on  television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the SUNG PHRASE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And give me money and have a teacher  there and a person to braid my hair  and color my face and give me  clothes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sung phrase again.

dialogues.speaker: ON MATT
dialogues.text: Stricken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wait here, Jeannie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several people milling about... Matt eyes Cathy. We still hear Jeannie's muffled singing from the other side of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) I have to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Matt and Cathy come into frame... Matt forcefully plac her with her back to the wall. She is not one to be pushe around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in hell is wrong with you? You  actually think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to hang in here but  everything in me cuts off when  somebody acts this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing right  along) ...that you can have my kid audition  for a show without asking me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't... She went for water and  by the time she got back, they had  offered her the part. Blame Burke,  he was there...

dialogues.text: Matt takes this in. Just a millimeter underneath his fury professional curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the part, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white kid in a multi-racial foster  home with all these kids of varying  ages. It's not a bad show. I sure  can't wait to see the test.

dialogues.text: How were they able to test her so  fast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They offered it to her off the  reading. I meant your test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... A child actor. Just what any  kid with problems needs to straighten  out--a series of her own...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy has nothing to offer. Matt begins leading her back. HOLD ON THEIR BACKS and see the chink in Matt's confidenc hear the tightness in his voice as he asks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll let me know as soon as they  see my test?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right away... You've got my vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie, a script in her lap, caressing it, avoiding her  father's gaze. He sits nearby sizing her up, pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if I don't let you. That's the  law, the police law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes this shot hard, but tries to pretend otherwise, continuing to stare hard at her script to avoid him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have to learn to read to be on  television?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a real edge) You're going to have to learn to  look at me and listen to me and the  longer I have to wait THE ANGRIER  I'M GOING TO BE.

dialogues.text: (looks up suddenly) I'm so mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. Just listen.

dialogues.text: I don't... why?!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I know about this. I have  worked with kid actors... They don't  have that much fun. They're inside  all day... they don't get to go to  regular schools or play with their  regular friends like Ricky and Essa. (progressively losing  it) And their parents? You think I'm  going to be one of those parents,  sitting in one of those rooms, where  we all go crazy trying to jump start  our egos with our kids' sweat, all  the time smiling at each other like  our lives are working while we root  against everyone else's little girl? (Jeannie is totally  confused, until) No!! No way! I can't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. So, no, you're cuckoo anyway.  I won't do it. And I don't care  because I'm be stupid at it anyway.

Burke sits n to Nan on a sofa--Cathy sits in front of him--others in c or on the floor. One ASSISTANT is attempting to "fine tun the color--the TINT BAR GRAPH is on screen sliding betwee and - as the color changes. Burke talks sotto to Nan.

dialogues.text: So how do you think 'Ground Zero'  will do tonight?

dialogues.text: (to himself) How bad can it be? We've got to have  at least a two million dollar Friday.  There's nothing else out there.

dialogues.text: (wearily) Everything doesn't boil down to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) Matt... (louder) Matt... Matt... Maybe it would be  easier if I just said 'hi' to her...  Hi, Jeannie... Yes, it's exciting...  No, no. He's right, honey, they get  somebody to read it to you. Now, put  your dad on--it's important. No,  first put your dad on... DAMN IT! (she waits a beat) ...Matt. Uh-huh, a few hours ago...  They all... everyone liked your work,  but I think they'll go for a name or  something.

dialogues.text: She listens to him. He is hurt. Cathy, though, is also  wrestling with her own internal struggles. She has betray him and is ashamed; in a strange way--terrified. She is,  therefore, just a little irritable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) It's not a matter of doing it  differently... they liked what you  did, a lot... they laughed and...  it's not you... it's them. (suddenly her breath  comes weird) No, please. Don't thank me. If you  feel like getting together later or  anytime, call me, okay? You sound  like you have your hands full right  now... Goodbye.

dialogues.text: As he hangs up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to talk to her again...  I...

dialogues.text: She stops in mid-sentence, looking at her father. He is  overcome... his energy failing to get him past this most  awful moment in his life. She moves to his side. He start to cry and, urgently seeking privacy, he moves quickly to the bathroom, rubbing Jeannie in an instinctive gesture o reassurance. He closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: ON JEANNIE
dialogues.text: Devoid of anger. Sympathy so pure that it wrenches. She s to move towards the bathroom. Her voice sweet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad? Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt opens the door quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's okay... I'm sorry I  forgot to put you back on with Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks across the room, Jeannie tracking him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't cried because of that...  I don't even want to talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt sits down, still suffering a bit of dysfunction, una to keep up appearances other than a few minor half-hearte tweaks at his daughter who stands solemn and silent at hi side. She pets him some... this goes on for several beats the STRAINS OF "YOU COULD BE WONDERFUL" accompany the mom Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Dad. Can I say just one thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With some effort, Matt lifts his head and nods permission

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to make me supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt nods, rises and leads her into the small kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke is wearing a T-shirt and shorts as he walks to his  four-stops-past-state-of-the-art Stairmaster and turns it while looking over his shoulder at the telephone... now  sucking in some courage, he goes to the phone and speed d He begins to climb the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have reached the Warner's Hotline.  Estimated Box Office Grosses for  Friday, December 3rd, Weekend Number  49, are as follows in millions of  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He braces himself... there is a tone, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Due to the high volume of calls, we  must ask you to wait till a line is  clear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC IN... At first from the speaker phone... Burke movi in time to "THERE IS A LONELY..." And now singing... As t lyric concludes and the instrumental comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) Thanks for waiting. Weekend 49 grosses  follow in millions of dollars.  'Belligerence,' 714 theaters. Two- point-one-eight million, down 46  percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke smiles with pleasure... his steps becoming lighter, more fanciful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) 'Best Girl,' 1,820 theaters, six- point-four million, up 24 percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuously) Cappuccino movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opening this weekend, 'Double Dare  Two,' 1,870 theaters, fourteen-point- three million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and now his film, "Ground Zero," is coming up to bat.. as succor to the gods, he tries to make his dance gleeful anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) 'Ground Zero,' 2,110 theaters, no  million, point four thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke falls off his Stairmaster and, from his new positio finishes his song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt is driving. Burke is seated alongside him, talking  without looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to pieces... (whispering) The picture was budgeted at 21 million  and I spent 49 so they were a little  mad at me to begin with. Now it  doesn't open even with an Arby's  Roast Beef tie-in... I mean, we only  averaged 300 dollars a theater...  they're going to think I'm Woody  Allen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you have to worry about  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. But this is private. What  about the exit survey? Did we do  good with any group at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we HEAR Nan's voice on the speakerphone which Burke h been addressing all along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't hear you, but--hi, Matt-- that was funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'I don't think you have to worry  about that?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs delightedly. Burke leans across Matt's lap to closer to the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did we do well with any group at  all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven-year-old boys in the South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits stupified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) Burke? Burke? Matt, is he...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you later. Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, hon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hits the "end" button. He slumps for a second, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all alone... (pause) At least there's that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the car arrives outside Popcorn Pictures, we can SEE s child actors and their parents arriving at the sound stag next door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to need me? The kids  are rehearsing and I'd like to take  a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. I have to stay inside  during lunch hours now anyway--that's  when everybody returns my calls  because they're trying to miss me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed) Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (misinterpreting) Yeah. Thanks for the support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A row of parents standing near their child actors, adjust them--not unlike handlers of racing Greyhounds.

dialogues.speaker: ON JEANNIE
dialogues.text: Seen from a distance--her father behind her. In the  foreground, the mass of workers on the stage, It is, in  effect, her POV, even though she is in the extreme backgr of the shot. We MOVE CLOSER to Jeannie and her father--ev a bit behind them. Jeannie is scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet I know what it looks like to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A giant "find Waldo."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite herself, she smiles at the reference, though her  tone is a bit sarcastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes, children, then we need  you for work on the set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That pretend living room, right over  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Set. Bye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding her arm) Wait a second, Jeannie. Let Daddy  give you a few tips here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (twisting away) Nooo. I've got to get to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She breaks free, depriving Matt of the sweet and simple m he wanted with her. She's one of the first ones on the se other kids still hugging their parents. As Cathy comes up behind Matt, we can HEAR Jeannie who, having so small a t for her father, needs to confirm what he just told her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faintly) Is this the set?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parents to Room Two, please. (as he goes by Matt) Parents to Room Two, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie is watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) We have to clear the set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt looks him off fiercely. The Passing Voice addresses friendlier parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) This way, parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad I found you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER AREA
dialogues.text: As they walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You holding up? What did you do last  night after I called?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if teasing) What do you think I did? I cried  like a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. So you don't want to  tell me. Be a tough guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel relieved just seeing you after  all that stuff... whew... Okay. (preparing to go) Burke wants to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever go out with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy is as simple and direct as she is embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You slept with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hate it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eventually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reeling a bit) Good Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the thing that makes me  nervous about you... You keep on  assuming I'm nicer than I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her. She kisses back. Then there is an  extraordinarily loud and piercing voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAD!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to see Jeannie beckoning to him from the stage-- director, standing at her side, joins in. He walks to the

dialogues.speaker: STAGE FULL OF ACTORS
dialogues.text: The Director is talking to Jeannie who seems, even from a distance, distraught and lost. She sees Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's such trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's very worried about being able  to pretend cry when she has to and  she doesn't get it about memorizing.  That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aghast) That's all?!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Director beckons Matt to lead her away. He does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't going to be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not with that attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She seems stung by this, unusually vulnerable. He changes tactics, softening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) It's just that they... Well, did  they tell you what an audience is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insulted) I know what an audience is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Now, because there's an  audience, they want you to know all  the words you have to say really  well. And since you can't read yet... (off her fierce look) ...you're going to have to be patient  and try hard. I can help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grasps at this unlikely straw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you help me to cry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (on her broad disbelief) I can. I can help make it okay. Trust  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie pauses half a beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss my mother bigger than you  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt on phone, Jeannie standing next to him reaching for phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jeannie) Not yet. Don't grab. (into phone) Thank you. We really appreciate this.  Hi, Beth. I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie grabs the phone in a flash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly into phone) Mom? No... Nothing... Nothing...  Nothing. Nothing... Would you talk?  I'd just like to listen to you...  Wait. Let me sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie sits herself by the window, protected by an iron  grill, and sits listening to her mother. There is about t pose something prescient; unmistakably, Jeannie will look this way again as a young woman cloaked in the love of so guy... but for now it's her mother, her crazy mother, who blots out dread. Matt is struck by how quiet and adoring  Jeannie looks even as he moves to give his daughter some  privacy. Several beats, Jeannie noticing her Dad looking her--switching positions, body language indicating that s wants to put him out of her mind... then a thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad says he's going to make me to  really cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie, your mom's not going to  understand what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie shushes him, resisting with surprising will and  strength when he tries to get the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Matt) She understands!!! (into phone) He's being terrible right now. (faster; avoiding  Matt) I love, loved, the coloring book you  sent me. Goodbye. Wait. I love you.  Let me hang up first. Love you. Send  me a letter. Bye. And a beaded T- shirt. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up. Matt pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you let me be on your side  for a second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't even understand what you're  saying now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what trust means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means that even if something is  hard to believe, you believe someone  you trust because you know he wouldn't  say it unless it were true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. So I don't trust  anybody, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think you get the concept.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't make sense. I don't  understand you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie reacts broadly... indicating what a difficult man she's stuck with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just know that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okayyyy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving up) You want to help me make a phone  call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes quickly to the phone and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven... two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hitting numbers) Who are we calling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy. She's very nice. One... six...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard to read) "Very nice..." One...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she answers phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi... (to Matt) What now?

dialogues.speaker: MATT'S VOICE IN BACKGROUND
dialogues.text: Tell her, 'How are you' and then let me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie... I can't talk now because...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, my dad wants to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I can't talk 'cause I'm on  the phone with a director...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to talk to you very much  and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) I can't. I have to hang up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie, truly stung by the hang-up. She takes this act o Cathy's as an insult to herself and her father. Matt does feel too wonderful about it himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to understand that sometimes  people are too busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So she's too busy for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Nan eating together on an elevated balcony  overlooking the main eating area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We look like jerks eating here this  early. Everybody's going to think we  couldn't get a reservation for the  hot hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you do this to yourself? Why  do you insist on eating dinner in a  restaurant where you're bound to see  all the people you're afraid of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you call it when you think  that what a group of people think of  you can confirm or destroy any decent  idea you have of yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did little Jeannie do today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it something that they have  you testing the TV show?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I asked was, how did Jeannie  do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody else. Jeannie. How did she  do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to me like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (really pissed) I want to be treated as if I'm really  saying words to you which you engage  and respond to. I like Matt; I'd  like to know how his daughter did.  So before you take your dance of  desperation across the restaurant  and I end up feeling so sorry for  you that I could die, I would like  you to answer my question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She did okay... and don't worry about  Matt... If the pilot sells, his kid  will be making five thousand a week.  So what do you know about 'People  Get Hurt?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm told that they're not going to  release it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew. I knew. What the hell are  you smiling for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me. But telling you about  this latest failure of yours--it  pleases me. I have no idea why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't be with someone who's not  rooting for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I am. It's just that rooting  for you is a good deal more  complicated than you realize. (as he rises) Don't go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'm not that mad. I  gotta do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC IN as Burke leaves the table. This "Dance of  Desperation" is classical. Burke himself lifting one of t women in greeting, then, as he puts her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) Sorry. I thought you were someone  else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he continues to go from table to table.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON NAN
dialogues.text: As she looks down on him, dying for him, we HEAR her sing the song "Poor Bastards". Finally, not only about Burke-- the other damaged souls he seeks to dance with. Now, Nan take no more. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: As he sees her go past in the background, he goes after h finally grabbing her near the Maitre D' station. This, ju as TWO IMPORTANT COUPLES arrive. Burke frantically tries cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nan, you know Victor and his wife... (he mumbles, unable  to remember any wife's  name) and Jay and his wife... (he mumbles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm sorry I can't talk now. I'm  very upset about what's happening to  Burke, so I just made up my mind I  can't be witness to it anymore if I  love him and I certainly shouldn't  be here if I don't... so I was just  in the process of leaving when he  stopped me and you folks walked in...  I'm sure you've had something like  this happen to you some time... some  horrible thing in your personal life  happening in public.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all nod and ad-lib agreements with her premise to Bu amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) Thank you for understanding. (to Burke) Goodbye. I wish only good things for  you even though I feel I've been  really damaged by this relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits, enormously upset. Burke, torn between followin her and repairing the social damage. But the couples are  paying him no mind; rather they are impressed with Nan. A they comment, i.e.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't that spectacular? I've never  seen anybody that secure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke accepts the compliments as if meant for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you. We're very  close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The strains of "Poor Bastards" underscoring the moment as Burke rushes into the parking area and grabs Nan's hand j as a valet brings her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand that I'm  exhausted from hurting. I'm through  with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins to cry. Ordinarily this would be a scene which would be unendurable for Burke. However, the lesson of a  moment ago is not lost on him. As people get out of cars witness the sobbing Nan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to restaurant patrons) Excuse me, we're working our shit  out... I'm sure it happened to you...  you know, private stuff in public.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reaction to his openness is disdain and passing conte She drives off, leaving Burke hurt and alone. "Poor Basta up and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lighting soft and sweet. Jeannie's words are tentativ as she talks to her father who sits watching intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I've been bad. I  know somebody's been bad. (hopefully) ...maybe it's you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt laughs. Jeannie looks at him shyly... he looks at he with encouragement. Suddenly she is in his arms, hugging hard, an emotional dam seems to have broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I love you so much, I love you  so much... I love you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt holds on--clearly, deeply moved. Then he exercises t effort to control his emotions and speaks, surprisingly, a Black woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Black woman) I hope that makes you feel a whole  lot better, Chile... 'Cause it sure  goes a long way to cure what ails  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as himself, coaching) ...got in this much...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...got in this much trouble. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Over a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (guessing) Word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. 'I can't believe I got in this  much trouble over a word.' Now do  you know what she means when she  says that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk about it--just  say her stuff so I know mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to flail a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your choice... But I'm not  helping unless you try to understand  as well as memorize. It will be fun.  Come on. I know it's hard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything to shut me up, huh? Okay,  this little girl you're pretending  to be... she can't be with her Mommy  either, just like you, or her  father... she has to stay in Rainbow  House which is called that because... (Jeannie starts  fidgeting) Jeannie... (she stops) ...because everyone's a different  color... so when this little girl  calls the black lady who takes care  of all the children this terrible  word... it's like the worst thing  anybody can do... Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaching him) I don't want to do the 'I love you'  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I might have been working you  too hard on that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is unable to resist muttering one sarcastic shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Why don't you do that with  poopie Cathy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring her) Now, did the director tell you how  he wanted you to do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said to smile all the time almost  and to talk... uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. We don't always get good  directors, so it's important for  us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me. You're not in the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm referring to the family of actors,  you little shithead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie doesn't know quite how to take the name calling.  MUSIC IN... we're heading for a rendezvous with a dance a it CONTINUES ACROSS THE CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt and Jeannie walking from the catering truck. They ar eating ravenously. MUSIC CONTINUES... VERY JOYOUS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a breakfast burrito. It's what  actors eat when they're working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, let's work a little more. The  most important acting you do is when  you listen. You're worried about  being able to cry when you're supposed  to, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. So much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there are really only two ways  to do it. Think of something that  makes you really sad... or forget  you're you and really forget you're  pretending...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I do that one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt reads from script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as a furious Black  woman) 'Don't test me, child! I could eat  you for lunch when I was your age  and I'm a hell of a lot bigger now!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie looks afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it... You just looked at me  and acted right without even thinking.  And there are games you can play to  help you with this. Get up... (she does) Now, be my mirror... do exactly what  I do... that's it... now, at a certain  point, I'm going to become your  mirror, but I'm not going to tell  you when... you tell me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) Now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically) Okay. We're going to make up words.  The words aren't what matter now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on a roof...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a great dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a... (then stops; then  smiles at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This acting exercise of Chicago's Story Theater leads int the song, "BE MY MIRROR." As the song finishes, Matt and  Jeannie are in the best spirits we've seen as an A.D.  approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They need you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the A.D.'s hand as Matt calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome. Don't mention it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy is in mid conversation with Millie. Matt enters and boldly says his piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a free man. Let's go to your  house and break the answering machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I could get away now. But  I've got a big meeting later. We'd  better take two cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Millie, having been at the screen test viewing, is taken  aback, looking from one to the other. Cathy knows what sh thinking and is unnerved, feeling silently accused, as sh leads Matt out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you later. Thanks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy's car followed by Matt in Burke's car. The frame ho both cars close as if this were one long car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She seems troubled. Then a decision. She dials a number o her mobile phone and picks up the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. He punches the speaker button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope it's you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt waves...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted) So this is how the big ones make  out.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO CARS
dialogues.text: Almost bumper to bumper... snuggling.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: She takes a breath and then plunges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he hears one of the more ominous phrases of the motion picture community.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt, will you take me off the  speaker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the phone. We intercut between the cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hyper) I don't know whether I'm being a  coward for telling you this way or  brave for telling you period... Can  you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I better talk fast because this  is where my phone always kicks out...  When we did your screentest... Can  you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I sort of folded on you at the  end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pauses, silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't like what I did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. Truly. But the discussion got  sort of dumb. It was a question of  sexiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what it came down to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sort of, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You folded on whether or not I'm  sexy. You don't think I'm sexy...  and you expressed that to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll tell you. I certainly  must think so pretty much because I  feel great about where we're going  now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a longish line of cars behind Matt and Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you very mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You were just... Aw, damn it, I  am. Very. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt manages to pull to the side... the other cars gobbli the places behind Cathy, who sees this... and now she wat Matt's car recede from her view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy going out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: ON MATT
dialogues.text: As he lets her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is in bed, wearing a bathrobe, watching projection TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...number seven at the box office  this week-end is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He switches channels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the two words are Tom Cruise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He switches channels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...becoming the first lawyer to be  awarded his own star on Hollywood  Boule...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns off the TV and crosses to the phone, allowing us read the back of his bathrobe "ROCKY BALBOA."

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: He looks at the clock which reads "four a.m." and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Nan. I hope it's not too late  to call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has been crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like another chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You only think you feel that way  because you're on the verge of failure  and you're without a core...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See. Nobody else gets me. (a beat then) You wanna have a little sex, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat then) You know I've never hung up on anybody  in my life... because what if the  next thing they said solved  everything... but I must end this  conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nan hangs up. Burke picks up a pocket electronic notepad  from the bedstand and hits the scroll button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Names and phone numbers.

dialogues.speaker: ON BURKE
dialogues.text: He scrolls past numbers, considering, finding them wantin so that, finally, he is scrolling the emptiness of his  relationships. Now he considers one number and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Matt, this is Burke. I'm sorry  to bother you at home, but you know  Nan... We were going out a little  and I could use another guy's slant  on what's just happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I can get into this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Did I catch you at a bad time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worse. You caught me at a bad time  you caused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean about the screentest.  The whole room thought you did good  work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reinventing irony) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, look, I'm not going to bother  you about my thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Okay, good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he hangs up. Looks down and turns off his phone number pocket computer. MUSIC RECALLS Prince's "There is Lonely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC SEGUES to recall "I'LL DO ANYTHING," as he drives p the line waiting to see RAINBOW HOUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Jeannie's face in the mirror, but it is seen throu something resembling fleece, which we now recognize as th strands of Jeannie's hair being combed out to the side by expert hair-dresser. Jeannie is shifting nervously in the large room where each chair is filled with a child of a  different age and color. In the b.g., we can HEAR the voi of the WARM-UP MAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...pilot for a new show called  'Rainbow House'. Just listen to our  band and I'll be back to tell you  more and make you love me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience laughs thinly. The BAND PLAYS as someone clo the door to the make-up room muffling the offstage sound. There is a good deal of tension in the brightly lit room. Jeannie sits between a FOURTEEN-YEAR-OLD HISPANIC BOY and FOUR-YEAR-OLD ASIAN GIRL. The room is abuzz... kids runni lines and loudly talking... this builds to a musical life in our first audition scene... there is a briefly sung ph (Jeannie not taking part).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The parents, in the same variety of skin colors as the ch actors, are stuffed into a small room being patronized by the ASSISTANT DIRECTOR. Matt is grimly seated in the midd of a long sofa containing stage mothers. Another sofa is feet away; the parents strain at each other. The A.D. is  talking grandly but we cannot hear his words because the  Rainbow Parents are SINGING a phrase from the same song w heard in the make-up room. Matt does not take part in the singing. The music goes under allowing us to now hear the A.D.'s words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and when you're in the audience,  make sure you laugh and applaud even  when it's somebody else's kid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is appreciative laughter from everyone save Matt, w rises in disgust and crosses out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again) You're not allowed near the stage.  We only have a few minutes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt ignores him and exits.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC NOW EMPHASIZING THE TENSION OF THE PRE-SHOW ATMOSPH
dialogues.text: Matt, moving about the area, looking for Jeannie, spots a cluster of other cast members excitedly awaiting their  introduction. Jeannie not among them. An A.D. talks with  concern to a P.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me know if you see the little  white girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt, growing concerned, walks on, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the stage to the distant make-up room. Jeannie, al in the room, which is so brightly lit it creates a bizarr effect, as if she were under a surreal spotlight. MUSIC  reprises Jeannie's Sinead O'Connor song, "Lonely Life of  Mine."

dialogues.speaker: ON MATT
dialogues.text: Stopping his impulse to go to her--he continues to observ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie is nervous and uncertain... She plays with the ha of the make-up chair... turns herself back and forth... T a very attractive TEN-YEAR-OLD BOY enters the scene--obvi telling her to hustle... He offers his hand and she takes it, instinctively masking all clues that this hand holdin is a "first" of great moment in her life. As they move to the main stage area, Jeannie looks around, needing  something... her dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns--sees her father and gives a small, cursory nod He moves quickly, drawing even with her but still giving a bit of space and a low-key pep talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just remember. You're not even here  tonight. There's only this other  little girl that you're pretending  to be who lives at Rainbow House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and who just vomited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt breaks up. Even Jeannie smiles briefly, then she tak him aside for privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just found out that we bow before  we even do anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And everybody claps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made up a great bow. You going to  look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't miss it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to be able to cry.  It's too hard for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, then they'll just give you more  chances after everyone leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This does not satisfy her. She rolls her eyes as she is p away towards the front of the stage. Matt watches as the year-old veteran actor leads his little daughter towards debut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC, a tension-filled version of "Poor Bastard." Burke' stride was never stronger, his posture never worse; head  hunched down into his neck. Suddenly, he reacts as he see the staff of Popcorn Pictures grouped together backstage. Cathy walking towards the group hurriedly from one direct as Burke approaches from the other. Seeing his staff has  clearly moved Burke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at you. You're all here because  of what's on the line for me tonight.  Having this many people in your corner  helps more than I would have ever  guessed. I'm just very grateful that  I made you come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts off, but a jubilant Cathy stops him, whispers  something. He reacts with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: She sees Matt deep in the wings watching the stage. She c to him with some urgency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt. Matt. Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and she beckons him towards her. With some hesit he joins her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to miss her introduction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk fast. It's amazing news.  Oliver Stone's been looking for a  comedy and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted) I've got to see my kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her voice breaking) ...he's doing my picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Part of this involves you. He  remembers you from 'Platoon' and  wants to use you in this one. (he stops) Got your attention, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt is terminally disappointed in her last cynical sente

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Cathy. Look, I'm going to watch  this. Let me talk to you later or  tomorrow. Thanks for your help. It's  good news. Gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the stage, we HEAR the VOICE of the WARM-UP MAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, in her first appearance ever,  Jeannie Hobbs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is applause. Matt's missed her intro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why couldn't you wait till later?  Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (broadly) I guess it's because I'm just  incredibly insensitive to all human  needs. I'd ask you to save me, but  I'm so far gone, I wouldn't want you  to waste your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reacts, but he walks off, not wanting to get into it. Cathy, however, has had a tricky nerve struck. She contin biting off each word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I don't have a kid or a  mate or a talent. (holding up book bag) I got this. (she's quite upset) And shoot me if I think it's  important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy, who looks alone and adorable as we HEAR MUSIC of " LONELY LIFE OF MINE." He puts a comforting hand on her. S speaks nakedly from deep within herself; her eyes downcas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm a superficial jerk. (and then a whispered  afterthought) You can't be right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're the best of the bunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (broadly) Oh, great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now she raises her eyes--big, blue and vulnerable. If this look were returned, "I love yous" could flow--they c sink to the floor in a joint epiphany; but there is no ro or kindling in Matt's eyes. He is in a hurry. Pridefully, Cathy turns and walks off in the opposite direction, her  flight so instinctive, she forgets her book bag. We hold this--her exit, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing just behind the four television cameras, immedia behind them, the "rail" where the Show's Staff and Crew  Members and Network Bosses stand crowded, choreographed i the way in which they "clear" for a moving camera. Behind these people is the studio audience. There is a loud laug Burke turns around to study the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy faces accompanied by the strains of Burke's love so to the crowd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Matt) What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Matt doesn't hear him... a few feet away, Jeannie is  making ready for her big moment. Three cameras swing in f of them, TV monitors showing a MASTER and CLOSE-UPS of th three characters in the scene: a short comic WHITE MAN, t Black Female Lead, and Jeannie, dressed as a poor child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wide-eyed) Wait. This is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like everyone is pi... ticked  off at me because I'm not colored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The White Man jumps on the phrase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (correcting her  pompously) The word is black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (correcting him with  booming voice) The word is African American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A burst of laughter, whooping and applause from the audie Burke brags in a whisper to Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had them bring in two busloads of  people from black churches.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: As they play out the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scolding Jeannie) Now you use it in a sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me, I...

dialogues.speaker: ON JEANNIE
dialogues.text: And Jeannie begins to falter... she must somehow cry at t moment... She looks outward for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at the Lead Actress giving Jeannie all she can.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO JEANNIE
dialogues.text: Jeannie still can't cry. She looks past the cameras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her father nervously pulling for her.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO JEANNIE
dialogues.text: That didn't do it either. She looks into herself... she b there are tears running down her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awwwww.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt, very much as he was when he watched Brando on the  plane... and then some. Burke, craning to make sure the  network bosses are suitably transported.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Use it in a sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying fully) Look at me. I love an African  American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me. I love a little redneck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Black Lead Actress holds out her arms to Jeannie, who tears streaming down her face, runs towards the arms...

dialogues.speaker: ON BURKE
dialogues.text: His lips pursed tightly in pleasure, then agape in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie has run past the Lead Actress and off the set, go into her father's arms instead. She jumps on him, her leg and arms wrapped around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pridefully) You little stinker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You big stinker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My little stinker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My big stinker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The background to this intimacy is enormously alive. The  Lead Actress and the Character Actor laughing out loud. I the b.g., we see the audience filling out preview cards a the FLOOR MANAGER leans in to say:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Jeannie. Take a minute.  We just need to get that hug at the  end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Floor Manager) Amazing, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jeannie) You were great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. That's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved it, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt starts to walk her back to the set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to put you down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her answer surprises him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. This is okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... Now, you're not finished  until you hug the lady just like you  did me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts her down. She turns from him to go back to work b on impulse, he restrains her. He is kneeling down, holdin her lightly by the arms, her back to him as he states an  ultimate truth:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very proud of you. I love you  more than anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie, shocked by her father's unprecedented sentiment, turns to face him and clamp a hand over his mouth so he w add no more lush and primal affection. Having silenced hi though, she finds that she has something of her own to sa She'd never tell it to her father, but she can't resist  telling it to her acting coach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I had to cry, I thought of you  buried in the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat, then) Give me a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cast of Rainbow House taking off their make-up, chang clothes, etc. This is more than high energy and excitemen what's the opposite of trauma? All are off the wall with  pleasure--the MUSICAL LIFE of the earlier dressing room s returning--peaks of glee resulting in sung phrases as bef Jeannie enters and is immediately surrounded with love,  attention and ad-libbed compliments about her work. In th glare of good will, Jeannie turns gloriously shy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea how special you  were? (on Jeannie's goony  reaction) That looks like a 'yes.' You've got  to get dressed for the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overwhelmed) There's more? (then) What will I wear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to wardrobe; they'll give you  anything you want.

dialogues.speaker: ON JEANNIE
dialogues.text: She moves to her dressing table--sits, looks in the mirro and giggles uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt stands waiting for Jeannie. Nan approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't sell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This show didn't sell?!? How do you  know so fast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the first time they had me do  cards for a pilot and the demographics  are all wrong for after nine o'clock.  That's their only opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie exits the make-up room aglow. She is wearing an  incredibly stylish outfit and her hair is in an expertly  done intricate braid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm Nan. I'm a good friend of  your Dad's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Nan. I'm Jeannie. Did you see  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jeannie) Yes, and you were wonderful. (aside to Matt) 89 percent likeability. (to Jeannie) And knowing that you were that good  means so much more than the show not  going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. (to Matt) I couldn't help it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does she mean? (to Nan) What do you mean? (to Matt) What does she mean? (to Nan) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That they're not going to be doing  any more of these shows right now-- but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (struck) Oh, my God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that means they're not going to  have a party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They're still having the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (totally relieved) Oh... really?... good... can we stay  late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To which Matt answers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, we're going to close the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to the roof garden opens and Jeannie enters--her dad behind her as she sees the party... the sparkling lig the decorations, the other kids and MUSIC... our opening  song... "WOW".

dialogues.speaker: ON JEANNIE
dialogues.text: As her father urges her into the flow. She passes Millie, who is dancing with the boy who held Jeannie's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cast him so he has to dance with  me, but I'm sure he'd prefer dancing  with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jeannie) Come on. You know how?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily, with disdain) Yesssssss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They begin to dance with the others. MUSIC SLOWS IN TEMPO we indicate TIME PASSAGE and:

dialogues.speaker: BURKE AND MATT
dialogues.text: Perched on a ledge eyeing the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not comfortable with television  anyway... it's too small... I'm much  better at something with size... I  don't do itzy. Even this movie of  Cathy's--it's small... medium small.  But with Stone it takes on a certain  volume where I start to feel  comfortable. (out of nowhere) I hate my life... (backtracking) ...in a way. I had a drink in my  office. I'm confused. You're not  saying anything. Is it because you're  not listening or because I haven't  stopped talking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Oliver Stone thing... does he  really want me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Oh, yeah. I forgot to say  congratu...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which part?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the two leads wouldn't be  bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's the crippled factory owner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best part in the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets off the ledge and starts to move away... Burke mo quickly to cut him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see my kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A second--look, they're taking the  cast picture now anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeannie, working her way to the absolute middle of the ca picture, where she plops on someone's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't look anything like the  women I usually go with. And you  know what they say, "beauty fades."  What they don't say is that it fades  very slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think I can tell you what  to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Only I can do that. I want you  to tell me what to feel... (he begins to use his  fingers to run down  Nan's qualities) Look. I trust her. More important,  everyone does. You have no idea how  impressed people are with her. She's  smart. She's interesting. You never  know what she'll say next... Her  work is amazing. I like talking to  her. You have no idea what to expect  next. I respect what she does more  than any writer or director--sincerely-- much more unusual--much more  important. So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks away. Burke waves a grateful goodbye and looks a the room until he sees:

dialogues.speaker: NAN ACROSS THE ROOF
dialogues.text: Nan eating cake with her hands. She sees him. He indicate he would like to dance. She does not move a muscle in  response... Still, he walks towards her. She begins to sh her head, "no." He shifts uncomfortably, but keeps coming until he reaches her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dance with me. (she shakes her head) On a business basis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (he turns away,  dejected) But I'll dance with you because I  think it will reassure me that I  should have nothing to do with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you breathing so heavy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nervous... Look, let's move our thing  in a more regular direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me think. (then) What if we go out this weekend... (before she can say  "no") ...with your kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several more beats of dancing--as he awaits her answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...whose name is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose name is... (then, triumphantly) Leslie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SONG BACK--"WOW"... sung as a chorus... a slower cadence the romance as we... CHANGE MUSIC and they dance more clo The song slows for time passage and MUSIC CHANGES to "BE MIRROR" as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt and Jeannie--the last ones there. He holds her in hi arms, dancing. She is asleep. He dances her to a chair wi her wrap on it... shifts her around, wrestling to get it She wakes up and puts it on herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around  satisfied) Last ones here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her hand and starts to lead her towards the stai shed--then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never got to see your bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up, smiling pridefully, to see her father smili back pridefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if it's a great  sacrifice) Oh, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bows. It is a bow all her own.
